", "suffix": "Establishing aconceptual framewo", "type": "TextQuoteSelector"}], "source": "https://arxiv.org/ftp/arxiv/papers/1603/1603.04939.pdf"}], "updated": "2018-10-16T23:30:17.068393+00:00", "tags": [], "uri": "https://arxiv.org/ftp/arxiv/papers/1603/1603.04939.pdf", "group": "__world__", "text": "This is so true, falls into the clicktavism debate that just because people click on a link, sign a petition, or have something to say online, it does not mean it is always effective.", "id": "cGv2dtGbEeiRRM85TImazQ", "document": {"title": ["Microsoft Word - GrandChallenges_altmetrics-revised.docx"]}, "user": "acct:mawaters@hypothes.is", "links": {"html": "https://hypothes.is/a/cGv2dtGbEeiRRM85TImazQ", "json": "https://hypothes.is/api/annotations/cGv2dtGbEeiRRM85TImazQ", "incontext": "https://hyp.is/cGv2dtGbEeiRRM85TImazQ/arxiv.org/ftp/arxiv/papers/1603/1603.04939.pdf"}}, {"created": "2018-10-16T22:41:28.892433+00:00", "permissions": {"read": ["group:__world__"], "update": ["acct:mawaters@hypothes.is"], "delete": ["acct:mawaters@hypothes.is"], "admin": ["acct:mawaters@hypothes.is"]}, "user_info": {"display_name": null}, "hidden": false, "flagged": false, "target": [{"selector": [{"end": 14242, "start": 14232, "type": "TextPositionSelector"}, {"prefix": "ng and reviewing (e.g., Reddit, ", "exact": "F1000Prime", "suffix": ")The different purposesand funct", "type": "TextQuoteSelector"}], "source": "https://arxiv.org/ftp/arxiv/papers/1603/1603.04939.pdf"}], "updated": "2018-10-16T22:41:28.892433+00:00", "tags": [], "uri": "https://arxiv.org/ftp/arxiv/papers/1603/1603.04939.pdf", "group": "__world__", "text": "I've never heard of this so I looked it up. F1000Prime was launched in 2002.

F1000Prime identifies and recommends important articles in biology and medical research publications. Articles are selected by a peer-nominated global 'Faculty' of the world's leading scientists and clinicians who then rate them and explain their importance. 

(https://f1000.com/prime/about/whatis) ", "id": "nxm54tGUEei770e4xTVUZA", "document": {"title": ["Microsoft Word - GrandChallenges_altmetrics-revised.docx"]}, "user": "acct:mawaters@hypothes.is", "links": {"html": "https://hypothes.is/a/nxm54tGUEei770e4xTVUZA", "json": "https://hypothes.is/api/annotations/nxm54tGUEei770e4xTVUZA", "incontext": "https://hyp.is/nxm54tGUEei770e4xTVUZA/arxiv.org/ftp/arxiv/papers/1603/1603.04939.pdf"}}, {"created": "2018-10-16T22:29:36.209641+00:00", "permissions": {"read": ["group:__world__"], "update": ["acct:camilleweinsheimer@hypothes.is"], "delete": ["acct:camilleweinsheimer@hypothes.is"], "admin": ["acct:camilleweinsheimer@hypothes.is"]}, "user_info": {"display_name": "camilleweinsheimer"}, "hidden": false, "references": ["PVFCus9vEei9AhNDDQ50zg"], "flagged": false, "target": [{"source": "https://arxiv.org/ftp/arxiv/papers/1603/1603.04939.pdf"}], "updated": "2018-10-16T22:29:36.209641+00:00", "tags": [], "uri": "https://arxiv.org/ftp/arxiv/papers/1603/1603.04939.pdf", "group": "__world__", "text": "I think this is a fair fear - something that isn't too difficult to imagine. A bit further down in the paper there is mention of  "timestamps" which had me thinking that maybe there could be some sort of "metric" (sorry, word of the day...) that could indicate where or how these counts are coming from: for example, X paper receives Y cites, but with further investigation, Z cites came from the same website/ IP address (just throwing this out there...) within a certain timeframe.", "id": "9k3eetGSEei-tB8J-gbaQA", "document": {"title": ["Microsoft Word - GrandChallenges_altmetrics-revised.docx"]}, "user": "acct:camilleweinsheimer@hypothes.is", "links": {"html": "https://hypothes.is/a/9k3eetGSEei-tB8J-gbaQA", "json": "https://hypothes.is/api/annotations/9k3eetGSEei-tB8J-gbaQA", "incontext": "https://hyp.is/PVFCus9vEei9AhNDDQ50zg/arxiv.org/ftp/arxiv/papers/1603/1603.04939.pdf"}}, {"created": "2018-10-16T22:14:11.625832+00:00", "permissions": {"read": ["group:__world__"], "update": ["acct:camilleweinsheimer@hypothes.is"], "delete": ["acct:camilleweinsheimer@hypothes.is"], "admin": ["acct:camilleweinsheimer@hypothes.is"]}, "user_info": {"display_name": "camilleweinsheimer"}, "hidden": false, "references": ["DTGR0tGDEeip-tONnpTMSQ"], "flagged": false, "target": [{"source": "https://arxiv.org/ftp/arxiv/papers/1603/1603.04939.pdf"}], "updated": "2018-10-16T22:14:11.625832+00:00", "tags": [], "uri": "https://arxiv.org/ftp/arxiv/papers/1603/1603.04939.pdf", "group": "__world__", "text": "I suppose I'm surprised by a lack of relationship because I would expect that researchers and those interested in the science would link to the source - so I'd expect that someone may provide the ultra-Cliff's-Notes version in a tweet, but then offer circulation of the original work. On  the  other  hand,  Twitter  and  Mendeley coverage ismuch  higher  at  around  10-20%  and  60-80%(Haustein,  Costas,  &  Larivière,  2015;  Priem,  Piwowar,  & Hemminger, 2012; Thelwall & Wilson, 2015; Waltman & Costas, 2014).", "suffix": " This reflects both the lower le", "type": "TextQuoteSelector"}], "source": "https://arxiv.org/ftp/arxiv/papers/1603/1603.04939.pdf"}], "updated": "2018-10-16T06:11:28.050765+00:00", "tags": [], "uri": "https://arxiv.org/ftp/arxiv/papers/1603/1603.04939.pdf", "group": "__world__", "text": "I'm really curious about the demographic of each of these platforms are considered. (i.e. Social media sites like Twitter are more frequented by people outside the academic community, while metrics from citation/reference tools more likely indicate researcher engagement.)

What type of engagement is more valuable to RPT processes? Just think of the New York Times, Wall Street Journal, any of the top women's mags, even just our local paper, the Georgia Straight.... Virtually all major mainstream publications are now optimized for online reading. Going "digital" doesn't mean simply posting a PDF version of your publication; from design to editorial to marketing, it's an entirely different form of publishing. It's so strange that scholarly journals haven't really adapted their process to the online environment yet. Is this really how we want to determine which research gets done / results get published?

The irony of this particular situation is also delightful. We want to evaluate the quality (rather than quantity) of dissemination of ideas. This likely has to do with the difficulties of integrating altmetrics into scholarly research because of its changing nature. Echoing an earlier sentiment in this paper, I think that altmetrics should not be integrated completely, but complementary to other research methods that we have. Even more so by its broad definition. 

I understand that this is discipline-specific writing, but this topic could have been presented in a more accessible way to the lay person. ", "id": "Qsffqs_tEeiu6Pszb3mBdg", "document": {"title": ["Microsoft Word - GrandChallenges_altmetrics-revised.docx"]}, "user": "acct:anastasiak@hypothes.is", "links": {"html": "https://hypothes.is/a/Qsffqs_tEeiu6Pszb3mBdg", "json": "https://hypothes.is/api/annotations/Qsffqs_tEeiu6Pszb3mBdg", "incontext": "https://hyp.is/Qsffqs_tEeiu6Pszb3mBdg/arxiv.org/ftp/arxiv/papers/1603/1603.04939.pdf"}}, {"created": "2018-10-14T20:08:48.849623+00:00", "permissions": {"read": ["group:__world__"], "update": ["acct:anastasiak@hypothes.is"], "delete": ["acct:anastasiak@hypothes.is"], "admin": ["acct:anastasiak@hypothes.is"]}, "user_info": {"display_name": null}, "hidden": false, "flagged": false, "target": [{"selector": [{"end": 2099, "start": 1990, "type": "TextPositionSelector"}, {"prefix": "nto  scholarly communication,  a", "exact": "s  researchers increasingly use  themto raise  their  visibility,  connect withothers  and  diffuse  their  w", "suffix": "ork (Rowlands,  Nicholas,  Russe", "type": "TextQuoteSelector"}], "source": "https://arxiv.org/ftp/arxiv/papers/1603/1603.04939.pdf"}], "updated": "2018-10-14T20:08:48.849623+00:00", "tags": [], "uri": "https://arxiv.org/ftp/arxiv/papers/1603/1603.04939.pdf", "group": "__world__", "text": "A possible answer to the question: how do we make research accessible to the general public?

Researchers would have the burden of making their research understandable to the lay man, and also of disseminating their information through informal (as opposed to professional channels) social media.", "id": "9ntpWs_sEeiswav7CDR-tA", "document": {"title": ["Microsoft Word - GrandChallenges_altmetrics-revised.docx"]}, "user": "acct:anastasiak@hypothes.is", "links": {"html": "https://hypothes.is/a/9ntpWs_sEeiswav7CDR-tA", "json": "https://hypothes.is/api/annotations/9ntpWs_sEeiswav7CDR-tA", "incontext": "https://hyp.is/9ntpWs_sEeiswav7CDR-tA/arxiv.org/ftp/arxiv/papers/1603/1603.04939.pdf"}}, {"created": "2018-10-14T03:03:55.127269+00:00", "permissions": {"read": ["group:__world__"], "update": ["acct:michelle_la@hypothes.is"], "delete": ["acct:michelle_la@hypothes.is"], "admin": ["acct:michelle_la@hypothes.is"]}, "user_info": {"display_name": "Michelle"}, "hidden": false, "flagged": false, "target": [{"source": "https://arxiv.org/ftp/arxiv/papers/1603/1603.04939.pdf"}], "updated": "2018-10-14T06:12:34.261041+00:00", "tags": [], "uri": "https://arxiv.org/ftp/arxiv/papers/1603/1603.04939.pdf", "group": "__world__", "text": "I am inspired by the lack of inspiring discussion on altmetrics. We can't make a perfect system unless it exists for us to make improvements on.

I (hypothetically, kind of - not really) suggest that our PDC class submits a research proposal for funds to create our own open-source alt metric system for eventual beta testing. We have enough diverse and critical minds to think about the objectives and limitations of factors that would go into a social media research altmetric.", "id": "yVwqFs9dEeiCH_tSgMpTTQ", "document": {"title": ["Microsoft Word - GrandChallenges_altmetrics-revised.docx"]}, "user": "acct:michelle_la@hypothes.is", "links": {"html": "https://hypothes.is/a/yVwqFs9dEeiCH_tSgMpTTQ", "json": "https://hypothes.is/api/annotations/yVwqFs9dEeiCH_tSgMpTTQ", "incontext": "https://hyp.is/yVwqFs9dEeiCH_tSgMpTTQ/arxiv.org/ftp/arxiv/papers/1603/1603.04939.pdf"}}, {"created": "2018-10-14T05:08:51.086325+00:00", "permissions": {"read": ["group:__world__"], "update": ["acct:Cgursche@hypothes.is"], "delete": ["acct:Cgursche@hypothes.is"], "admin": ["acct:Cgursche@hypothes.is"]}, "user_info": {"display_name": null}, "hidden": false, "flagged": false, "target": [{"selector": [{"end": 21022, "start": 20992, "type": "TextPositionSelector"}, {"prefix": "tmetrics  are dynamic, whichcan ", "exact": "be altered or deleted entirely", "suffix": ". I think having a beta version of an open-source Altmetric would be worth giving a shot. We can't perfect anything unless we put it into practice

I think researchers and consumers of research (hopefully) would be able to take any altmetric measure with a grain of salt. In our social media age, I think most people have awareness for the reasons why something goes viral (e.g. its really bad or good). In my opinion, my initial impression upon hearing the word 'bullshit' is that the person that is expressing it without due consideration. However, I think that this could be the intended effect of spreading so-called fake news. The public may more easily dismiss careless bullshit instead of something more sinister. 
In my opinion, reducing these stories to bullshit may do more harm to public perception, but the word itself still generates a fair amount of public attention, however shallow.", "id": "s0uKgredEeiyPrOw8IdtNA", "document": {"title": ["On Bullshit"]}, "user": "acct:cypriine@hypothes.is", "links": {"html": "https://hypothes.is/a/s0uKgredEeiyPrOw8IdtNA", "json": "https://hypothes.is/api/annotations/s0uKgredEeiyPrOw8IdtNA", "incontext": "https://hyp.is/0bfXzrZNEeigoM90ihHqIw/www2.csudh.edu/ccauthen/576f12/frankfurt__harry_-_on_bullshit.pdf"}}, {"created": "2018-09-13T21:31:46.585462+00:00", "permissions": {"read": ["group:__world__"], "update": ["acct:cypriine@hypothes.is"], "delete": ["acct:cypriine@hypothes.is"], "admin": ["acct:cypriine@hypothes.is"]}, "user_info": {"display_name": null}, "hidden": false, "references": ["u24ifrcbEeiA2b9TEMY3ZA"], "flagged": false, "target": [{"source": "http://www2.csudh.edu/ccauthen/576f12/frankfurt__harry_-_on_bullshit.pdf"}], "updated": "2018-09-13T21:31:46.585462+00:00", "tags": [], "uri": "http://www2.csudh.edu/ccauthen/576f12/frankfurt__harry_-_on_bullshit.pdf", "group": "__world__", "text": "The difficulty for me is that the author's definition is so broad, and as the others have commented, a little bit of a stretch. I am leaning more towards the latter of your interpretation, but I can not decisively say that his speech is made entirely in the name of self-preservation. If I understand this correctly, later, the author goes on to imply that the orator perhaps believes in his words less than what they are meant to convey about him to his audience. This is an interesting point, just not one I am sure if I can agree with. Certainly the orator is being nationalistic, but I think the key is that he is hyperbolic. The hyperbole could be considered as short of a lie , which then could neatly be considered 'humbug' by Black's definition. Of course, it would be ignorant not to acknowledge that the speech being considered humbug is entirely dependent on the audience's perspective, and their kind of truth.", "id": "QLSMvrebEeiVn-dA2Dk7qA", "document": {"title": ["On Bullshit"]}, "user": "acct:cypriine@hypothes.is", "links": {"html": "https://hypothes.is/a/QLSMvrebEeiVn-dA2Dk7qA", "json": "https://hypothes.is/api/annotations/QLSMvrebEeiVn-dA2Dk7qA", "incontext": "https://hyp.is/sJL_5rUnEei8Hmf7qKYVbA/www2.csudh.edu/ccauthen/576f12/frankfurt__harry_-_on_bullshit.pdf"}}, {"created": "2018-09-13T20:40:31.460228+00:00", "permissions": {"read": ["group:__world__"], "update": ["acct:linnteetzel@hypothes.is"], "delete": ["acct:linnteetzel@hypothes.is"], "admin": ["acct:linnteetzel@hypothes.is"]}, "user_info": {"display_name": null}, "hidden": false, "references": ["uLgU0LUyEeiow-MS_NElQg"], "flagged": false, "target": [{"source": "http://www2.csudh.edu/ccauthen/576f12/frankfurt__harry_-_on_bullshit.pdf"}], "updated": "2018-09-13T20:40:31.460228+00:00", "tags": [], "uri": "http://www2.csudh.edu/ccauthen/576f12/frankfurt__harry_-_on_bullshit.pdf", "group": "__world__", "text": "I have read this article at least twice, and have not found it helpful for my understanding of the issues we face. In many cultures, especially that are more collectivist orientated there isn't the idea of the self or it is not developed in the way it is on Eurocentric/ethnocentric teachings that we have been exposed to in North America. Therefore, the idea of a self in these societies can be challenging to understand and  to conceive", "id": "DShLmLcsEeiVpwsCOaoYPA", "document": {"title": ["On Bullshit"]}, "user": "acct:michelle_la@hypothes.is", "links": {"html": "https://hypothes.is/a/DShLmLcsEeiVpwsCOaoYPA", "json": "https://hypothes.is/api/annotations/DShLmLcsEeiVpwsCOaoYPA", "incontext": "https://hyp.is/DShLmLcsEeiVpwsCOaoYPA/www2.csudh.edu/ccauthen/576f12/frankfurt__harry_-_on_bullshit.pdf"}}, {"created": "2018-09-13T08:04:04.876247+00:00", "permissions": {"read": ["group:__world__"], "update": ["acct:michelle_la@hypothes.is"], "delete": ["acct:michelle_la@hypothes.is"], "admin": ["acct:michelle_la@hypothes.is"]}, "user_info": {"display_name": "Michelle"}, "hidden": false, "flagged": false, "target": [{"selector": [{"end": 44004, "start": 43849, "type": "TextPositionSelector"}, {"prefix": "est representations of himself. ", "exact": "Convinced that reality has noinherent nature, which he might hope to identify as the truthabout things, he devotes himself to being true to his own nature.", "suffix": "It is as though he decides that ", "type": "TextQuoteSelector"}], "source": "http://www2.csudh.edu/ccauthen/576f12/frankfurt__harry_-_on_bullshit.pdf"}], "updated": "2018-09-13T08:04:04.876247+00:00", "tags": [], "uri": "http://www2.csudh.edu/ccauthen/576f12/frankfurt__harry_-_on_bullshit.pdf", "group": "__world__", "text": "I don't buy this. I don't think most people have the time to be thinking about the nature of their reality or be solipsistic. It is a rather privileged position to be in to be able to spend one's time pondering about the social construction of reality.

The author also fails to provide examples of what he means as "anti-realist" doctrines. So I am just speaking on my interpretation of his writing.

In practice, perhaps what the author is talking about are those who believe in "alternative facts" are anti-realists. I think it takes a lot of time, education, intellectual engagement to b able to triangulate data, and be media literate -- i.e. privileged, in order to really have an 'objective' view on the world. While the author does state that objectivity may never be achieved but its a goal, he fails to consider what type of society/culture, education system, values, institutions, resources are needed to create a democracy of "informed" citizens. 

I think for many people in the world their sense of reality is based on patterns they see, socialization,  personal experiences, in addition to appeals of authority, etc, So I think we should be more understanding of where and why anti-realist doctrines come from in social life", "id": "lTJt5LcrEeiU92tssTtHcg", "document": {"title": ["On Bullshit"]}, "user": "acct:michelle_la@hypothes.is", "links": {"html": "https://hypothes.is/a/lTJt5LcrEeiU92tssTtHcg", "json": "https://hypothes.is/api/annotations/lTJt5LcrEeiU92tssTtHcg", "incontext": "https://hyp.is/lTJt5LcrEeiU92tssTtHcg/www2.csudh.edu/ccauthen/576f12/frankfurt__harry_-_on_bullshit.pdf"}}, {"created": "2018-09-13T07:46:19.553141+00:00", "permissions": {"read": ["group:__world__"], "update": ["acct:michelle_la@hypothes.is"], "delete": ["acct:michelle_la@hypothes.is"], "admin": ["acct:michelle_la@hypothes.is"]}, "user_info": {"display_name": "Michelle"}, "hidden": false, "flagged": false, "target": [{"selector": [{"end": 42278, "start": 42078, "type": "TextPositionSelector"}, {"prefix": "wing what he is talking about. T", "exact": "husthe production of bullshit is stimulated whenever a person’sobligations or opportunities to speak about some topic are moreexcessive than his knowledge of the facts that are relevant to thattopic. ", "suffix": "This discrepancy is common in pu", "type": "TextQuoteSelector"}], "source": "http://www2.csudh.edu/ccauthen/576f12/frankfurt__harry_-_on_bullshit.pdf"}], "updated": "2018-09-13T07:46:19.553141+00:00", "tags": [], "uri": "http://www2.csudh.edu/ccauthen/576f12/frankfurt__harry_-_on_bullshit.pdf", "group": "__world__", "text": "Perhaps bullshit is a manifestation of convenience?", "id": "GjhHeLcpEei--EdE8L7eeg", "document": {"title": ["On Bullshit"]}, "user": "acct:michelle_la@hypothes.is", "links": {"html": "https://hypothes.is/a/GjhHeLcpEei--EdE8L7eeg", "json": "https://hypothes.is/api/annotations/GjhHeLcpEei--EdE8L7eeg", "incontext": "https://hyp.is/GjhHeLcpEei--EdE8L7eeg/www2.csudh.edu/ccauthen/576f12/frankfurt__harry_-_on_bullshit.pdf"}}, {"created": "2018-09-13T07:42:16.275146+00:00", "permissions": {"read": ["group:__world__"], "update": ["acct:michelle_la@hypothes.is"], "delete": ["acct:michelle_la@hypothes.is"], "admin": ["acct:michelle_la@hypothes.is"]}, "user_info": {"display_name": "Michelle"}, "hidden": false, "flagged": false, "target": [{"selector": [{"end": 34975, "start": 34851, "type": "TextPositionSelector"}, {"prefix": "sier than the task of the liar. Like many other cognitive biases, this belief that we're competent at recognizing bs, or that it's a problem concerning "other people, but not myself because I'd know bs if I saw it" can be dangerous in some contexts when we overestimate our own abilities/behaviours. ", "exact": "Someone who lies and someonewho tells the truth are playing on opposite sides, so to speak, inthe same game. Each responds to the facts as he understandsthem, although the response of the one is guided by the authorityof the truth, while the response of the other defies that authorityand refuses to meet its demands. The bullshitter ignores thesedemands altogether.", "suffix": " He does not reject the authorit", "type": "TextQuoteSelector"}], "source": "http://www2.csudh.edu/ccauthen/576f12/frankfurt__harry_-_on_bullshit.pdf"}], "updated": "2018-09-12T21:50:31.431535+00:00", "tags": [], "uri": "http://www2.csudh.edu/ccauthen/576f12/frankfurt__harry_-_on_bullshit.pdf", "group": "__world__", "text": "It's a game in which truth-tellers and liars are diametrically opposed; and in which the bullshitter is cheating. Or, at the very least, isn't following the same rules to. 

The bullshitter doesn't care about the rules, because the rules are related to the truth and the truth doesn't matter - winning matters. I think it's worth considering the gender implications of 'bull' as a choice for the metaphorical output of nonsense and falsehood — not 'hen shit', for instance.

I have never seen the term "bull session" used before though, so I'm at a bit of a loss for the nuances of its meaning. The [OED](http://www.oed.com.proxy.lib.sfu.ca/view/Entry/24494?redirectedFrom=bull+session#eid12482927) says it originates in the US, but does not offer much enlightenment beyond what Frankfurt presents here.", "id": "EUSdvLZVEeiYix9sI9UJog", "document": {"title": ["On Bullshit"]}, "user": "acct:melissa_roach@hypothes.is", "links": {"html": "https://hypothes.is/a/EUSdvLZVEeiYix9sI9UJog", "json": "https://hypothes.is/api/annotations/EUSdvLZVEeiYix9sI9UJog", "incontext": "https://hyp.is/70dCcrXOEeigWhuCwF3GlQ/www2.csudh.edu/ccauthen/576f12/frankfurt__harry_-_on_bullshit.pdf"}}, {"created": "2018-09-12T06:09:04.814761+00:00", "permissions": {"read": ["group:__world__"], "update": ["acct:melissa_roach@hypothes.is"], "delete": ["acct:melissa_roach@hypothes.is"], "admin": ["acct:melissa_roach@hypothes.is"]}, "user_info": {"display_name": null}, "hidden": false, "references": ["Aa3herUtEeiYiI90UZrkuw"], "flagged": false, "target": [{"source": "http://www2.csudh.edu/ccauthen/576f12/frankfurt__harry_-_on_bullshit.pdf"}], "updated": "2018-09-12T06:09:04.814761+00:00", "tags": [], "uri": "http://www2.csudh.edu/ccauthen/576f12/frankfurt__harry_-_on_bullshit.pdf", "group": "__world__", "text": "I wonder if we might narrow this understanding as limited to things that are presented as truthful, despite the speaker's disregard for truth? Then we might comfortably exclude literature that is explicitly fictional.", "id": "Wgd3PrZSEeiDw4caYPV5qQ", "document": {"title": ["On Bullshit"]}, "user": "acct:melissa_roach@hypothes.is", "links": {"html": "https://hypothes.is/a/Wgd3PrZSEeiDw4caYPV5qQ", "json": "https://hypothes.is/api/annotations/Wgd3PrZSEeiDw4caYPV5qQ", "incontext": "https://hyp.is/Aa3herUtEeiYiI90UZrkuw/www2.csudh.edu/ccauthen/576f12/frankfurt__harry_-_on_bullshit.pdf"}}, {"created": "2018-09-12T06:04:29.401978+00:00", "permissions": {"read": ["group:__world__"], "update": ["acct:melissa_roach@hypothes.is"], "delete": ["acct:melissa_roach@hypothes.is"], "admin": ["acct:melissa_roach@hypothes.is"]}, "user_info": {"display_name": null}, "hidden": false, "flagged": false, "target": [{"selector": [{"end": 20467, "start": 20435, "type": "TextPositionSelector"}, {"prefix": "hat she does only in a somewhat ", "exact": "clumsy effort to speakcolorfully", "suffix": ", or to appear vivacious or good", "type": "TextQuoteSelector"}], "source": "http://www2.csudh.edu/ccauthen/576f12/frankfurt__harry_-_on_bullshit.pdf"}], "updated": "2018-09-12T06:04:29.401978+00:00", "tags": [], "uri": "http://www2.csudh.edu/ccauthen/576f12/frankfurt__harry_-_on_bullshit.pdf", "group": "__world__", "text": "Where do we draw the line between figurative language and untruth? When does the line blur in a deceptive way that could become problematic? 

[This piece I found](https://www.brainpickings.org/2018/03/26/nietzsche-on-truth-and-lies-in-a-nonmoral-sense/) quotes Nietzche on the consequences of lies as being of more concern than being lied to:

"What men avoid by excluding the liar is not so much being defrauded as it is being harmed by means of fraud. Thus, even at this stage, what they hate is basically not deception itself, but rather the unpleasant, hated consequences of certain sorts of deception."

Frankfurt acknowledges that Wittgenstein's reaction is extreme, but what is the general level of comfort for those of us who are not sticklers like Wittgenstein? Do we scale our tolerance for lies or misrepresentations according to the weight of their consequences?", "id": "td258rZREeiLlldMrYu7rw", "document": {"title": ["On Bullshit"]}, "user": "acct:melissa_roach@hypothes.is", "links": {"html": "https://hypothes.is/a/td258rZREeiLlldMrYu7rw", "json": "https://hypothes.is/api/annotations/td258rZREeiLlldMrYu7rw", "incontext": "https://hyp.is/td258rZREeiLlldMrYu7rw/www2.csudh.edu/ccauthen/576f12/frankfurt__harry_-_on_bullshit.pdf"}}, {"created": "2018-09-12T05:58:54.234258+00:00", "permissions": {"read": ["group:__world__"], "update": ["acct:KariGustafson@hypothes.is"], "delete": ["acct:KariGustafson@hypothes.is"], "admin": ["acct:KariGustafson@hypothes.is"]}, "user_info": {"display_name": null}, "hidden": false, "flagged": false, "target": [{"selector": [{"end": 5488, "start": 5474, "type": "TextPositionSelector"}, {"prefix": "racteristics of its own as well?", "exact": "Short of lying", "suffix": ": It must be part of the point o", "type": "TextQuoteSelector"}], "source": "http://www2.csudh.edu/ccauthen/576f12/frankfurt__harry_-_on_bullshit.pdf"}], "updated": "2018-09-12T05:58:54.234258+00:00", "tags": [], "uri": "http://www2.csudh.edu/ccauthen/576f12/frankfurt__harry_-_on_bullshit.pdf", "group": "__world__", "text": "This reminds me of the ongoing discussion in the US media about how to characterize the many untrue statements made by Donald Trump. ", "id": "7hVVBrZQEei19m8bmGGeYg", "document": {"title": ["On Bullshit"]}, "user": "acct:KariGustafson@hypothes.is", "links": {"html": "https://hypothes.is/a/7hVVBrZQEei19m8bmGGeYg", "json": "https://hypothes.is/api/annotations/7hVVBrZQEei19m8bmGGeYg", "incontext": "https://hyp.is/7hVVBrZQEei19m8bmGGeYg/www2.csudh.edu/ccauthen/576f12/frankfurt__harry_-_on_bullshit.pdf"}}, {"created": "2018-09-12T05:36:38.134357+00:00", "permissions": {"read": ["group:__world__"], "update": ["acct:melissa_roach@hypothes.is"], "delete": ["acct:melissa_roach@hypothes.is"], "admin": ["acct:melissa_roach@hypothes.is"]}, "user_info": {"display_name": null}, "hidden": false, "flagged": false, "target": [{"selector": [{"end": 14050, "start": 14017, "type": "TextPositionSelector"}, {"prefix": "be sure, suggest this.Excrement ", "exact": "is not designed or crafted at all", "suffix": "; it is merely emitted,or dumped", "type": "TextQuoteSelector"}], "source": "http://www2.csudh.edu/ccauthen/576f12/frankfurt__harry_-_on_bullshit.pdf"}], "updated": "2018-09-12T05:36:38.134357+00:00", "tags": [], "uri": "http://www2.csudh.edu/ccauthen/576f12/frankfurt__harry_-_on_bullshit.pdf", "group": "__world__", "text": "In light of the following conclusion that bullshit can indeed be carefully contrived, I wonder if the connotations of the word itself undermine the insidious nature of the deception described in the paragraph below. Is 'bullshit' the right word to call due attention to malignant public falsehoods?", "id": "0bfXzrZNEeigoM90ihHqIw", "document": {"title": ["On Bullshit"]}, "user": "acct:melissa_roach@hypothes.is", "links": {"html": "https://hypothes.is/a/0bfXzrZNEeigoM90ihHqIw", "json": "https://hypothes.is/api/annotations/0bfXzrZNEeigoM90ihHqIw", "incontext": "https://hyp.is/0bfXzrZNEeigoM90ihHqIw/www2.csudh.edu/ccauthen/576f12/frankfurt__harry_-_on_bullshit.pdf"}}, {"created": "2018-09-12T05:33:55.136879+00:00", "permissions": {"read": ["group:__world__"], "update": ["acct:KariGustafson@hypothes.is"], "delete": ["acct:KariGustafson@hypothes.is"], "admin": ["acct:KariGustafson@hypothes.is"]}, "user_info": {"display_name": null}, "hidden": false, "flagged": false, "target": [{"selector": [{"end": 37557, "start": 37384, "type": "TextPositionSelector"}, {"prefix": "e nor on the side of the false. He does not care whether theth", "type": "TextQuoteSelector"}], "source": "http://www2.csudh.edu/ccauthen/576f12/frankfurt__harry_-_on_bullshit.pdf"}], "updated": "2018-09-12T05:33:55.136879+00:00", "tags": [], "uri": "http://www2.csudh.edu/ccauthen/576f12/frankfurt__harry_-_on_bullshit.pdf", "group": "__world__", "text": "Getting away with what he says or getting what he wants.

I think there may be something here in the relationship of the parties. We wouldn't be able to "bullshit" someone who knew us well or intimately. That would be lying. 

Also, we would definitely try to bullshit our way through an interview or an exam essay, but would not lie. Unless we were stating an untrue opinion because we were afraid our true feelings would be judged negatively, which again comes back to the relationship question. To your question around the incapacity of words to represent meanings absolutely truthfully — and what that means for bullshit; I do think that intention factors in heavily.

The distance between the signifier and the signified allows space for confusion, and for exploitation. One thing that troubles me about these grey areas is the plausible deniability they afford to any would-be bullshitters. Perhaps a feature of 'bullshit' is that it must be able to plausibly masquerade as the truth.", "id": "XVMGWLZLEeiwOOP2tjHGeA", "document": {"title": ["On Bullshit"]}, "user": "acct:melissa_roach@hypothes.is", "links": {"html": "https://hypothes.is/a/XVMGWLZLEeiwOOP2tjHGeA", "json": "https://hypothes.is/api/annotations/XVMGWLZLEeiwOOP2tjHGeA", "incontext": "https://hyp.is/oyexCLXMEeishYvRhjVRww/www2.csudh.edu/ccauthen/576f12/frankfurt__harry_-_on_bullshit.pdf"}}, {"created": "2018-09-12T03:25:22.998153+00:00", "permissions": {"read": ["group:__world__"], "update": ["acct:KariGustafson@hypothes.is"], "delete": ["acct:KariGustafson@hypothes.is"], "admin": ["acct:KariGustafson@hypothes.is"]}, "user_info": {"display_name": null}, "hidden": false, "flagged": false, "target": [{"selector": [{"end": 24567, "start": 24417, "type": "TextPositionSelector"}, {"prefix": "are committed to what they say: ", "exact": "It isunderstood by everyone in a bull session that the statementspeople make do not necessarily reveal what they really believe orhow they really feel", "suffix": ". I feel that in both fields (advertising and politics) the problem is a bit more insidious.", "id": "joFz6LY5EeiwHM9Wq0AE-g", "document": {"title": ["On Bullshit"]}, "user": "acct:KariGustafson@hypothes.is", "links": {"html": "https://hypothes.is/a/joFz6LY5EeiwHM9Wq0AE-g", "json": "https://hypothes.is/api/annotations/joFz6LY5EeiwHM9Wq0AE-g", "incontext": "https://hyp.is/UfbEILUpEeixTm_5JcE9AQ/www2.csudh.edu/ccauthen/576f12/frankfurt__harry_-_on_bullshit.pdf"}}, {"created": "2018-09-12T02:58:07.392826+00:00", "permissions": {"read": ["group:__world__"], "update": ["acct:KariGustafson@hypothes.is"], "delete": ["acct:KariGustafson@hypothes.is"], "admin": ["acct:KariGustafson@hypothes.is"]}, "user_info": {"display_name": null}, "hidden": false, "flagged": false, "target": [{"selector": [{"end": 11276, "start": 11121, "type": "TextPositionSelector"}, {"prefix": "te a new beginning for mankind. ", "exact": "But the orator does notreally care what his audience thinks about the Founding Fathers,or about the role of the deity in our country’s history, or the like", "suffix": ".At least, it is not an interest", "type": "TextQuoteSelector"}], "source": "http://www2.csudh.edu/ccauthen/576f12/frankfurt__harry_-_on_bullshit.pdf"}], "updated": "2018-09-12T02:58:07.392826+00:00", "tags": [], "uri": "http://www2.csudh.edu/ccauthen/576f12/frankfurt__harry_-_on_bullshit.pdf", "group": "__world__", "text": "I don't know if I agree with this - the orator does care what the audience thinks about these things, just not in the sense of whether s/he cares if they believe them to be objectively true. But if they are trying to "convey a certain impression of himself," then they care deeply about how the audience is going to perceive the statements. Humbug is in this sense perhaps a situation where the orator and audience know that the statements are perhaps not true, but agree to disregard this as beside the point of the speech.", "id": "rN2CILY3Eei5Co85nHwmHw", "document": {"title": ["On Bullshit"]}, "user": "acct:KariGustafson@hypothes.is", "links": {"html": "https://hypothes.is/a/rN2CILY3Eei5Co85nHwmHw", "json": "https://hypothes.is/api/annotations/rN2CILY3Eei5Co85nHwmHw", "incontext": "https://hyp.is/rN2CILY3Eei5Co85nHwmHw/www2.csudh.edu/ccauthen/576f12/frankfurt__harry_-_on_bullshit.pdf"}}, {"created": "2018-09-12T02:33:39.051217+00:00", "permissions": {"read": ["group:__world__"], "update": ["acct:KariGustafson@hypothes.is"], "delete": ["acct:KariGustafson@hypothes.is"], "admin": ["acct:KariGustafson@hypothes.is"]}, "user_info": {"display_name": null}, "hidden": false, "references": ["j8SAkLSDEeizAc-tnyPPYA"], "flagged": false, "target": [{"source": "http://www2.csudh.edu/ccauthen/576f12/frankfurt__harry_-_on_bullshit.pdf"}], "updated": "2018-09-12T02:33:39.051217+00:00", "tags": [], "uri": "http://www2.csudh.edu/ccauthen/576f12/frankfurt__harry_-_on_bullshit.pdf", "group": "__world__", "text": "What about passing on something that someone else deliberately made up to mislead? How much individual responsibility does one have for uncritically passing on something that is untrue without verifying it?

In these cases, should persons with expertise in research / fact finding be held to a higher standard? (Like persons in a profession like teaching have a legal responsibility to report suspected child abuse, should researchers have a responsibility to report untruths?)", "id": "QabLXrY0Eeilglc6W19BHw", "document": {"title": ["On Bullshit"]}, "user": "acct:KariGustafson@hypothes.is", "links": {"html": "https://hypothes.is/a/QabLXrY0Eeilglc6W19BHw", "json": "https://hypothes.is/api/annotations/QabLXrY0Eeilglc6W19BHw", "incontext": "https://hyp.is/j8SAkLSDEeizAc-tnyPPYA/www2.csudh.edu/ccauthen/576f12/frankfurt__harry_-_on_bullshit.pdf"}}, {"created": "2018-09-11T14:57:20.561889+00:00", "permissions": {"read": ["group:__world__"], "update": ["acct:aliceLF@hypothes.is"], "delete": ["acct:aliceLF@hypothes.is"], "admin": ["acct:aliceLF@hypothes.is"]}, "user_info": {"display_name": "Alice Fleerackers"}, "hidden": false, "flagged": false, "target": [{"selector": [{"end": 40739, "start": 40685, "type": "TextPositionSelector"}, {"prefix": "toit at all. By virtue of this, ", "exact": "bullshit is a greater enemy of the truththan lies are.", "suffix": "One who is concerned to report o", "type": "TextQuoteSelector"}], "source": "http://www2.csudh.edu/ccauthen/576f12/frankfurt__harry_-_on_bullshit.pdf"}], "updated": "2018-09-11T14:57:20.561889+00:00", "tags": [], "uri": "http://www2.csudh.edu/ccauthen/576f12/frankfurt__harry_-_on_bullshit.pdf", "group": "__world__", "text": "So bullshit exists on a totally different pane of reality than truth and lies. It can exist independent of facts. It has no roots in the real world—or at least, it doesn't require them. ", "id": "c9EC6LXQEeiP2MsWyYs89w", "document": {"title": ["On Bullshit"]}, "user": "acct:aliceLF@hypothes.is", "links": {"html": "https://hypothes.is/a/c9EC6LXQEeiP2MsWyYs89w", "json": "https://hypothes.is/api/annotations/c9EC6LXQEeiP2MsWyYs89w", "incontext": "https://hyp.is/zYV-JLUuEeiupJer5WVYKA/www2.csudh.edu/ccauthen/576f12/frankfurt__harry_-_on_bullshit.pdf"}}, {"created": "2018-09-11T14:33:29.222027+00:00", "permissions": {"read": ["group:__world__"], "update": ["acct:aliceLF@hypothes.is"], "delete": ["acct:aliceLF@hypothes.is"], "admin": ["acct:aliceLF@hypothes.is"]}, "user_info": {"display_name": "Alice Fleerackers"}, "hidden": false, "flagged": false, "target": [{"selector": [{"end": 24892, "start": 24705, "type": "TextPositionSelector"}, {"prefix": " the subjects under discussion. ", "exact": "Therefore provision is made forenjoying a certain irresponsibility, so that people will beencouraged to convey what is on their minds without too muchanxiety that they will be held to it.", "suffix": "Each of the contributors to a bu", "type": "TextQuoteSelector"}], "source": "http://www2.csudh.edu/ccauthen/576f12/frankfurt__harry_-_on_bullshit.pdf"}], "updated": "2018-09-11T14:33:29.222027+00:00", "tags": [], "uri": "http://www2.csudh.edu/ccauthen/576f12/frankfurt__harry_-_on_bullshit.pdf", "group": "__world__", "text": "This also means that bull sessions create an opportunity for people to express thoughts or beliefs they wouldn't feel comfortable sharing otherwise—i.e. the opposite of bull shit. 

But of course, if it's said in the context of a bull session, the truth will be indistinguishable from the bull shit. Does it still count as telling the truth, if everyone things your just bullshitting? This sounds more like [#BroTalk](https://www.urbandictionary.com/define.php?term=Bro%20Talk)", "id": "70dCcrXOEeigWhuCwF3GlQ", "document": {"title": ["On Bullshit"]}, "user": "acct:aliceLF@hypothes.is", "links": {"html": "https://hypothes.is/a/70dCcrXOEeigWhuCwF3GlQ", "json": "https://hypothes.is/api/annotations/70dCcrXOEeigWhuCwF3GlQ", "incontext": "https://hyp.is/70dCcrXOEeigWhuCwF3GlQ/www2.csudh.edu/ccauthen/576f12/frankfurt__harry_-_on_bullshit.pdf"}}, {"created": "2018-09-11T14:22:09.191679+00:00", "permissions": {"read": ["group:__world__"], "update": ["acct:aliceLF@hypothes.is"], "delete": ["acct:aliceLF@hypothes.is"], "admin": ["acct:aliceLF@hypothes.is"]}, "user_info": {"display_name": "Alice Fleerackers"}, "hidden": false, "references": ["4U91eLUjEeiDEpdAdKAhig"], "flagged": false, "target": [{"source": "http://www2.csudh.edu/ccauthen/576f12/frankfurt__harry_-_on_bullshit.pdf"}], "updated": "2018-09-11T14:22:09.191679+00:00", "tags": [], "uri": "http://www2.csudh.edu/ccauthen/576f12/frankfurt__harry_-_on_bullshit.pdf", "group": "__world__", "text": "I think there's an interesting question tucked inside your question, which I think Black touches on later: Can you bullshit yourself? 

I think there are (at least) two possible ways the orator could be bullshitting in this example. He could be misrepresenting himself to give the audience a certain impression of himself. Or, he could be doing so to give himself a certain impression of himself... Who hasn't done that, to some degree? It's part of human nature.

See the [Dunning-Kruger](https://www.vox.com/science-and-health/2017/11/18/16670576/dunning-kruger-effect-video) effect. for example: “...psychological research suggests that we’re not very good at evaluating ourselves accurately. In fact, we frequently overestimate our own abilities.” 

Is misrepresenting yourself to yourself still bullshit? Does it matter if it's done intentionally or not?
 ", "id": "EVTK8rXOEeimQCsRG94nTA", "document": {"title": ["On Bullshit"]}, "user": "acct:aliceLF@hypothes.is", "links": {"html": "https://hypothes.is/a/EVTK8rXOEeimQCsRG94nTA", "json": "https://hypothes.is/api/annotations/EVTK8rXOEeimQCsRG94nTA", "incontext": "https://hyp.is/4U91eLUjEeiDEpdAdKAhig/www2.csudh.edu/ccauthen/576f12/frankfurt__harry_-_on_bullshit.pdf"}}, {"created": "2018-09-11T14:11:54.907010+00:00", "permissions": {"read": ["group:__world__"], "update": ["acct:aliceLF@hypothes.is"], "delete": ["acct:aliceLF@hypothes.is"], "admin": ["acct:aliceLF@hypothes.is"]}, "user_info": {"display_name": "Alice Fleerackers"}, "hidden": false, "flagged": false, "target": [{"selector": [{"end": 5807, "start": 5697, "type": "TextPositionSelector"}, {"prefix": "this cannot be the whole point. ", "exact": "After all, every use oflanguage without exception has some, but not all, of thecharacteristic features of lies", "suffix": " — if no other, then at least th", "type": "TextQuoteSelector"}], "source": "http://www2.csudh.edu/ccauthen/576f12/frankfurt__harry_-_on_bullshit.pdf"}], "updated": "2018-09-11T14:11:54.907010+00:00", "tags": [], "uri": "http://www2.csudh.edu/ccauthen/576f12/frankfurt__harry_-_on_bullshit.pdf", "group": "__world__", "text": "I love this strangely poetic moment in the essay. What's that famous Kafka quote again..."All language is but a poor translation"? 

It's funny how easy it is to forget that language is just a tool we've developed to attempt to describe reality to one another. [Words are stand-ins](http://open.lib.umn.edu/communication/chapter/3-1-language-and-meaning/) for the real things, feelings, thoughts, or sensations they are meant to convey—not true or complete reflections of the world. 

And if all language is, to some degree, a lie or misrepresentation, what does that mean for bullshit? Is it the person's intention—of wanting to fool or deceive vs communicate reality—that sets bullshit apart from other discourse? ", "id": "oyexCLXMEeishYvRhjVRww", "document": {"title": ["On Bullshit"]}, "user": "acct:aliceLF@hypothes.is", "links": {"html": "https://hypothes.is/a/oyexCLXMEeishYvRhjVRww", "json": "https://hypothes.is/api/annotations/oyexCLXMEeishYvRhjVRww", "incontext": "https://hyp.is/oyexCLXMEeishYvRhjVRww/www2.csudh.edu/ccauthen/576f12/frankfurt__harry_-_on_bullshit.pdf"}}, {"created": "2018-09-11T06:44:38.702085+00:00", "permissions": {"read": ["group:__world__"], "update": ["acct:melissa_roach@hypothes.is"], "delete": ["acct:melissa_roach@hypothes.is"], "admin": ["acct:melissa_roach@hypothes.is"]}, "user_info": {"display_name": null}, "hidden": false, "references": ["E3DcSLUmEeiD389xJlC9cg"], "flagged": false, "target": [{"source": "http://www2.csudh.edu/ccauthen/576f12/frankfurt__harry_-_on_bullshit.pdf"}], "updated": "2018-09-11T06:44:38.702085+00:00", "tags": [], "uri": "http://www2.csudh.edu/ccauthen/576f12/frankfurt__harry_-_on_bullshit.pdf", "group": "__world__", "text": "I did chuckle a bit at this. The purpose of the conversatio", "type": "TextQuoteSelector"}], "source": "http://www2.csudh.edu/ccauthen/576f12/frankfurt__harry_-_on_bullshit.pdf"}], "updated": "2018-09-10T19:16:57.756644+00:00", "tags": [], "uri": "http://www2.csudh.edu/ccauthen/576f12/frankfurt__harry_-_on_bullshit.pdf", "group": "__world__", "text": "I would disagree with this. ", "exact": "It is just this lack of connection to a concern with truth —this indifference to how things really are — that I regard as of theessence of bullshit.", "suffix": "Now I shall consider (quite sele", "type": "TextQuoteSelector"}], "source": "http://www2.csudh.edu/ccauthen/576f12/frankfurt__harry_-_on_bullshit.pdf"}], "updated": "2018-09-10T19:09:14.071406+00:00", "tags": [], "uri": "http://www2.csudh.edu/ccauthen/576f12/frankfurt__harry_-_on_bullshit.pdf", "group": "__world__", "text": "So in other words:
The intention of the speech act is completely dissociated with reality, truth, and the very notion of language as a tool for communicating the truth, first and foremost. 
I don't necessarily disagree, but I'm hoping he'll narrow the parameters here, because there's a whole lot of things that can fall into this category. Poetry, fiction, my beloved science fiction and fantasy novels, to name a few. ", "id": "Aa3herUtEeiYiI90UZrkuw", "document": {"title": ["On Bullshit"]}, "user": "acct:emmisalive@hypothes.is", "links": {"html": "https://hypothes.is/a/Aa3herUtEeiYiI90UZrkuw", "json": "https://hypothes.is/api/annotations/Aa3herUtEeiYiI90UZrkuw", "incontext": "https://hyp.is/Aa3herUtEeiYiI90UZrkuw/www2.csudh.edu/ccauthen/576f12/frankfurt__harry_-_on_bullshit.pdf"}}, {"created": "2018-09-10T19:01:30.725720+00:00", "permissions": {"read": ["group:__world__"], "update": ["acct:emmisalive@hypothes.is"], "delete": ["acct:emmisalive@hypothes.is"], "admin": ["acct:emmisalive@hypothes.is"]}, "user_info": {"display_name": null}, "hidden": false, "references": ["VGRZzLQFEei07Q9zHP8Cyw"], "flagged": false, "target": [{"source": "http://www2.csudh.edu/ccauthen/576f12/frankfurt__harry_-_on_bullshit.pdf"}], "updated": "2018-09-10T19:02:25.371998+00:00", "tags": [], "uri": "http://www2.csudh.edu/ccauthen/576f12/frankfurt__harry_-_on_bullshit.pdf", "group": "__world__", "text": "To me it seemed like she was repeating an idiom, sort of like tapping a language button that is meant to convey a commonly understood *generic* (or even "procrustean"?) meaning. In that case, the "mindlessness" or the drama would definitely be there, but Wittegenstein's response suggests that there is no room for anything other than direct language. "Don't be so dramatic"
Which obviously isn't realistic. Hers is not just any bad fee", "type": "TextQuoteSelector"}], "source": "http://www2.csudh.edu/ccauthen/576f12/frankfurt__harry_-_on_bullshit.pdf"}], "updated": "2018-09-10T18:54:01.326679+00:00", "tags": [], "uri": "http://www2.csudh.edu/ccauthen/576f12/frankfurt__harry_-_on_bullshit.pdf", "group": "__world__", "text": "And particularly excessive! ", "id": "4anlJLUqEei3FZcsBNNrYA", "document": {"title": ["On Bullshit"]}, "user": "acct:emmisalive@hypothes.is", "links": {"html": "https://hypothes.is/a/4anlJLUqEei3FZcsBNNrYA", "json": "https://hypothes.is/api/annotations/4anlJLUqEei3FZcsBNNrYA", "incontext": "https://hyp.is/4anlJLUqEei3FZcsBNNrYA/www2.csudh.edu/ccauthen/576f12/frankfurt__harry_-_on_bullshit.pdf"}}, {"created": "2018-09-10T18:52:16.137348+00:00", "permissions": {"read": ["group:__world__"], "update": ["acct:emmisalive@hypothes.is"], "delete": ["acct:emmisalive@hypothes.is"], "admin": ["acct:emmisalive@hypothes.is"]}, "user_info": {"display_name": null}, "hidden": false, "references": ["XCGmJrSKEeiiy291K3pLTw"], "flagged": false, "target": [{"source": "http://www2.csudh.edu/ccauthen/576f12/frankfurt__harry_-_on_bullshit.pdf"}], "updated": "2018-09-10T18:52:16.137348+00:00", "tags": [], "uri": "http://www2.csudh.edu/ccauthen/576f12/frankfurt__harry_-_on_bullshit.pdf", "group": "__world__", "text": "Its starting to seem like bullshit only really exists in the cracks between exchanges or as a lens applied from a certain angle. Someone else literally has to be there to run the grain in the other direction, but regardless if they do or don't, the ''bullshit' is still there. At moments it does seem like trying to define bullshit means eliminating any use of colourful or stylized language. There has got to be room for idioms and figures of speech, no? I'm not really buying the 'self-impression' motive. He may believe what he is saying, or he may not, but what does not change is the position from which he is speaking, and the audience he is speaking to. I feel as though there is definitely room in between those two objective points to recognize the humbuggery-- that being a statement and a motive which we cannot fully discern, yet one we are certain holds an ulterior agenda-- and to come up with a number of reasons as to the intentions of the orator. ", "id": "4U91eLUjEeiDEpdAdKAhig", "document": {"title": ["On Bullshit"]}, "user": "acct:emmisalive@hypothes.is", "links": {"html": "https://hypothes.is/a/4U91eLUjEeiDEpdAdKAhig", "json": "https://hypothes.is/api/annotations/4U91eLUjEeiDEpdAdKAhig", "incontext": "https://hyp.is/4U91eLUjEeiDEpdAdKAhig/www2.csudh.edu/ccauthen/576f12/frankfurt__harry_-_on_bullshit.pdf"}}, {"created": "2018-09-10T18:31:10.459351+00:00", "permissions": {"read": ["group:__world__"], "update": ["acct:emmisalive@hypothes.is"], "delete": ["acct:emmisalive@hypothes.is"], "admin": ["acct:emmisalive@hypothes.is"]}, "user_info": {"display_name": null}, "hidden": false, "flagged": false, "target": [{"selector": [{"end": 11120, "start": 10805, "type": "TextPositionSelector"}, {"prefix": "gests, the orator is not lying. ", "exact": "He would be lying only ifit were his intention to bring about in his audience beliefs whichhe himself regards as false, concerning such matters as whetherour country is great, whether it is blessed, whether the Foundershad divine guidance, and whether what they did was in fact tocreate a new beginning for mankind.", "suffix": " But the orator does notreally c", "type": "TextQuoteSelector"}], "source": "http://www2.csudh.edu/ccauthen/576f12/frankfurt__harry_-_on_bullshit.pdf"}], "updated": "2018-09-10T18:31:10.459351+00:00", "tags": [], "uri": "http://www2.csudh.edu/ccauthen/576f12/frankfurt__harry_-_on_bullshit.pdf", "group": "__world__", "text": "Summary: In order to lie, there needs to be an awareness of some kind of truth. I say "some kind of truth" because I don't want to eliminate personal truths/beliefs. 

I think we're getting close to the realm of alternative facts! ", "exact": "May any utterance at all qualify ashumbug or bullshit, given that (so to speak) the utterer’s heart isin the right place, or must the utterance have certaincharacteristics of its own as well?", "suffix": "Short of lying: It must be part ", "type": "TextQuoteSelector"}], "source": "http://www2.csudh.edu/ccauthen/576f12/frankfurt__harry_-_on_bullshit.pdf"}], "updated": "2018-09-09T22:56:17.983036+00:00", "tags": [], "uri": "http://www2.csudh.edu/ccauthen/576f12/frankfurt__harry_-_on_bullshit.pdf", "group": "__world__", "text": "I think if the utterer intends to mislead someone by fabricating what they are saying to any degree, it would be considered humbug or bullshit", "id": "j8SAkLSDEeizAc-tnyPPYA", "document": {"title": ["On Bullshit"]}, "user": "acct:mawaters@hypothes.is", "links": {"html": "https://hypothes.is/a/j8SAkLSDEeizAc-tnyPPYA", "json": "https://hypothes.is/api/annotations/j8SAkLSDEeizAc-tnyPPYA", "incontext": "https://hyp.is/j8SAkLSDEeizAc-tnyPPYA/www2.csudh.edu/ccauthen/576f12/frankfurt__harry_-_on_bullshit.pdf"}}, {"created": "2018-09-09T07:52:41.808216+00:00", "permissions": {"read": ["group:__world__"], "update": ["acct:CSG@hypothes.is"], "delete": ["acct:CSG@hypothes.is"], "admin": ["acct:CSG@hypothes.is"]}, "user_info": {"display_name": null}, "hidden": false, "flagged": false, "target": [{"selector": [{"end": 20263, "start": 20197, "type": "TextPositionSelector"}, {"prefix": "egard for how things really are.", "exact": "It is for this mindlessness that Pascal’s Wittgenstein chides her.", "suffix": "What disgusts him is that Pascal", "type": "TextQuoteSelector"}], "source": "http://www2.csudh.edu/ccauthen/576f12/frankfurt__harry_-_on_bullshit.pdf"}], "updated": "2018-09-09T07:52:41.808216+00:00", "tags": [], "uri": "http://www2.csudh.edu/ccauthen/576f12/frankfurt__harry_-_on_bullshit.pdf", "group": "__world__", "text": "But how is this mindlessness?
"I feel just like [what I imagine] a dog that has been run over [must feel like]."
Fania uses a metaphor to describe her feelings. Clearly, the imagination is implied, and imagination is anything but mindlessness.
met·a·phor
noun
a figure of speech in which a word or phrase is applied to an object or action to which it is not literally applicable.

If anything, the literal interpretation of the remark and resulting castigation is BS", "id": "VGRZzLQFEei07Q9zHP8Cyw", "document": {"title": ["On Bullshit"]}, "user": "acct:CSG@hypothes.is", "links": {"html": "https://hypothes.is/a/VGRZzLQFEei07Q9zHP8Cyw", "json": "https://hypothes.is/api/annotations/VGRZzLQFEei07Q9zHP8Cyw", "incontext": "https://hyp.is/VGRZzLQFEei07Q9zHP8Cyw/www2.csudh.edu/ccauthen/576f12/frankfurt__harry_-_on_bullshit.pdf"}}, {"created": "2018-09-07T21:37:58.266384+00:00", "permissions": {"read": ["group:__world__"], "update": ["acct:CSG@hypothes.is"], "delete": ["acct:CSG@hypothes.is"], "admin": ["acct:CSG@hypothes.is"]}, "user_info": {"display_name": null}, "hidden": false, "flagged": false, "target": [{"source": "http://www2.csudh.edu/ccauthen/576f12/frankfurt__harry_-_on_bullshit.pdf"}], "updated": "2018-09-07T21:37:58.266384+00:00", "tags": [], "uri": "http://www2.csudh.edu/ccauthen/576f12/frankfurt__harry_-_on_bullshit.pdf", "group": "__world__", "text": "Not necessarily. The BSer in Chief seems to operate on the principle of being fact adverse. He studiously ignores that which, although true, intrudes upon the state of mind that has him as the greatest in whatever field of endeavour he's currently addressing. Divorcing these words from their context of the afterlife, the thing about them that gives me pause is the question of who is authorized and trusted to conduct the research that yields this data.

It seems to me to create a sort of power imbalance if it is only university-educated people who decide what is hard truth and what is "anecdotal."

I don't think that is exactly what Carl Sagan is up to here, but that is what came to mind as I read this paragraph.", "id": "5IGUdrecEeiyPSeS-Rn9rA", "document": {"title": ["Microsoft Word - The Fine Art of Baloney Detection.doc"]}, "user": "acct:melissa_roach@hypothes.is", "links": {"html": "https://hypothes.is/a/5IGUdrecEeiyPSeS-Rn9rA", "json": "https://hypothes.is/api/annotations/5IGUdrecEeiyPSeS-Rn9rA", "incontext": "https://hyp.is/yJHlILePEeilnT9Or1eUIg/www.inf.fu-berlin.de/lehre/pmo/eng/Sagan-Baloney.pdf"}}, {"created": "2018-09-13T20:46:10.870705+00:00", "permissions": {"read": ["group:__world__"], "update": ["acct:michelle_la@hypothes.is"], "delete": ["acct:michelle_la@hypothes.is"], "admin": ["acct:michelle_la@hypothes.is"]}, "user_info": {"display_name": "Michelle"}, "hidden": false, "references": ["8c6b3LcvEeixylciBerwMw", "XsJTZLeUEei9uU8TVhd4eg"], "flagged": false, "target": [{"source": "http://www.inf.fu-berlin.de/lehre/pmo/eng/Sagan-Baloney.pdf"}], "updated": "2018-09-13T20:46:10.870705+00:00", "tags": [], "uri": "http://www.inf.fu-berlin.de/lehre/pmo/eng/Sagan-Baloney.pdf", "group": "__world__", "text": "Yes, absolutely - I hope I don't come off as a hyper cultural relativist -- I have criticisms on that camp as well. I absolutely do think that the scientific method and critical thinking should be the very foundation of understanding, but we just have to be mindful of when and where we apply the scientific method in understanding social phenomena", "id": "DAIjvreWEeic-G-RBh8f0g", "document": {"title": ["Microsoft Word - The Fine Art of Baloney Detection.doc"]}, "user": "acct:michelle_la@hypothes.is", "links": {"html": "https://hypothes.is/a/DAIjvreWEeic-G-RBh8f0g", "json": "https://hypothes.is/api/annotations/DAIjvreWEeic-G-RBh8f0g", "incontext": "https://hyp.is/8c6b3LcvEeixylciBerwMw/www.inf.fu-berlin.de/lehre/pmo/eng/Sagan-Baloney.pdf"}}, {"created": "2018-09-13T20:34:10.587469+00:00", "permissions": {"read": ["group:__world__"], "update": ["acct:linnteetzel@hypothes.is"], "delete": ["acct:linnteetzel@hypothes.is"], "admin": ["acct:linnteetzel@hypothes.is"]}, "user_info": {"display_name": null}, "hidden": false, "references": ["8c6b3LcvEeixylciBerwMw"], "flagged": false, "target": [{"source": "http://www.inf.fu-berlin.de/lehre/pmo/eng/Sagan-Baloney.pdf"}], "updated": "2018-09-13T20:34:10.587469+00:00", "tags": [], "uri": "http://www.inf.fu-berlin.de/lehre/pmo/eng/Sagan-Baloney.pdf", "group": "__world__", "text": "Hi Michelle,
I agree that we have to be careful in the way we judge people for all the reasons you have mentioned.  But it feels that we are in a period of crisis, and are searching for ways for people to assess what they are seeing and reading.  Sagan, the scientist, puts forward his belief in critical thinking and the scientific method.  I think this may be a place to start, but it's not enough.

", "exact": "What skeptical thinking boils down to is the means to construct, and to understand, a reasoned argument and—especially important—to recognize a fallacious or fraudulent argument. I wrote an [article](https://alicefleerackers.files.wordpress.com/2017/12/2017_sadmag_space-astrology.pdf
) earlier this year, investigating some of the reasons why astrology has become more popular than ever (25% of Americans believe in horoscopes, and that number is even higher among young people.) 

I spoke to two astrologers and a psychologist who studied belief, and they all agreed: believing in astrology, or any other kind of "puerile marvel", helps us feel more in control of our lives, feel like life has an order and a purpose. [Similar things have been said about yoga](https://www.chatelaine.com/living/books/wellmania-brigid-delaney/
) and other wellness trends. In an increasingly secular society, pseudoscience—bullshit—sometimes ends up taking the place organized religion traditionally would have. ", "exact": "Part of the success of the tobacco industry in purveying this brew of addictive poisons can be attributed to widespread unfamiliarity with baloney detection, critical thinking, and the scientific method.", "suffix": " Gullibility kills. 
        

 ", "type": "TextQuoteSelector"}], "source": "http://www.inf.fu-berlin.de/lehre/pmo/eng/Sagan-Baloney.pdf"}], "updated": "2018-09-13T08:36:45.340329+00:00", "tags": [], "uri": "http://www.inf.fu-berlin.de/lehre/pmo/eng/Sagan-Baloney.pdf", "group": "__world__", "text": "As someone who occasionally smokes --I know how bad cigarettes are. Yet, I still do it in the times that I do because I think it is rational to me to do so or the benefits outweigh the risks in the moment. E.g. "I really need this cigarette because it will help me get through my day, and I have 100 essays to mark"

I guess what I am trying to say is that we should be cognizant and to be cautious of the way we judge others for their lack of "critical thinking". The truth may be too much for them to grasp and seek an outside source to find the truth. For the cancer patients, they seek the help of psychics in order to achieve relief. They can't rest until they are relieved of the issue.", "id": "HsdvRpwCEeezJP8R0Cppng", "document": {"title": ["Microsoft Word - The Fine Art of Baloney Detection.doc"]}, "user": "acct:pkatcef@hypothes.is", "links": {"html": "https://hypothes.is/a/HsdvRpwCEeezJP8R0Cppng", "json": "https://hypothes.is/api/annotations/HsdvRpwCEeezJP8R0Cppng", "incontext": "https://hyp.is/HsdvRpwCEeezJP8R0Cppng/lti.hypothes.is/viewer/web/6aef3df90002fbfab1a43ce8eee5eb15.pdf"}}, {"created": "2017-09-17T23:42:05.627579+00:00", "permissions": {"read": ["group:__world__"], "update": ["acct:pkatcef@hypothes.is"], "delete": ["acct:pkatcef@hypothes.is"], "admin": ["acct:pkatcef@hypothes.is"]}, "user_info": {"display_name": null}, "hidden": false, "flagged": false, "target": [{"selector": [{"end": 7703, "start": 6755, "type": "TextPositionSelector"}, {"prefix": "are offered are banal homilies. ", "exact": "Here, to take another example, is a set of information channeled not from an ancient dead person, but from unknown non-human entities who make crop circles, as recorded by the journalist Jim Schnabel: We are so anxious at this sinful nation spreading lies about us. We do not come in machines, we do not land on your earth in machines ... We come like the wind. We are Life Force. Life Force from the ground ... Come here ... We are but a breath away ... a breath away ... we are not a million miles away ... a Life Force that is larger than the energies in your body. But we meet at a higher level of life ... We need no name. We are parallel to your world, alongside your world ... The walls are broken. Two men will rise from the past ... the great bear ... the world will be at peace. People pay attention to these puerile marvels mainly because they promise something like old-time religion, but especially life after death, even life eternal.", "suffix": " A very different prospect for s", "type": "TextQuoteSelector"}], "source": "https://lti.hypothes.is/viewer/web/6aef3df90002fbfab1a43ce8eee5eb15.pdf"}], "updated": "2017-09-17T23:42:05.627579+00:00", "tags": [], "uri": "https://lti.hypothes.is/viewer/web/6aef3df90002fbfab1a43ce8eee5eb15.pdf", "group": "__world__", "text": "Sagan again raises the question whether or not things are meant to be explained immediately. There would be no mental gain from everything be explained in the beginning. There is no grasp of acquiring knowledge on the topic or in depth thinking related to it. It must remain a mystery for those to think about it.", "id": "0BD4rpwBEeeInGefzmP33w", "document": {"title": ["Microsoft Word - The Fine Art of Baloney Detection.doc"]}, "user": "acct:pkatcef@hypothes.is", "links": {"html": "https://hypothes.is/a/0BD4rpwBEeeInGefzmP33w", "json": "https://hypothes.is/api/annotations/0BD4rpwBEeeInGefzmP33w", "incontext": "https://hyp.is/0BD4rpwBEeeInGefzmP33w/lti.hypothes.is/viewer/web/6aef3df90002fbfab1a43ce8eee5eb15.pdf"}}, {"created": "2017-09-17T23:38:57.331853+00:00", "permissions": {"read": ["group:__world__"], "update": ["acct:pkatcef@hypothes.is"], "delete": ["acct:pkatcef@hypothes.is"], "admin": ["acct:pkatcef@hypothes.is"]}, "user_info": {"display_name": null}, "hidden": false, "flagged": false, "target": [{"selector": [{"end": 3641, "start": 3178, "type": "TextPositionSelector"}, {"prefix": "se some reserves of skepticism. ", "exact": "How is it, I ask myself, that channelers never give us verifiable information otherwise unavailable? Why does Alexander the Great never tell us about the exact location of his tomb, Fermat about his Last Theorem, John Wilkes Booth about the Lincoln assassination conspiracy, Hermann Goring about the Reichstag fire? Why don’t Sophocles, Democritus, and Aristarchus dictate their lost books? Don’t they wish future generations to have access to their masterpieces?", "suffix": " If some good evidence for life ", "type": "TextQuoteSelector"}], "source": "https://lti.hypothes.is/viewer/web/6aef3df90002fbfab1a43ce8eee5eb15.pdf"}], "updated": "2017-09-17T23:38:57.331853+00:00", "tags": [], "uri": "https://lti.hypothes.is/viewer/web/6aef3df90002fbfab1a43ce8eee5eb15.pdf", "group": "__world__", "text": "Perhaps it is to keep future generations alive, a spark that ignites thinking and wonder. If everything is immediately explained, it might not be interesting for philosophers to dive into their thinking.", "id": "X8QY4pwBEeeb7IfWaCwyfQ", "document": {"title": ["Microsoft Word - The Fine Art of Baloney Detection.doc"]}, "user": "acct:pkatcef@hypothes.is", "links": {"html": "https://hypothes.is/a/X8QY4pwBEeeb7IfWaCwyfQ", "json": "https://hypothes.is/api/annotations/X8QY4pwBEeeb7IfWaCwyfQ", "incontext": "https://hyp.is/X8QY4pwBEeeb7IfWaCwyfQ/lti.hypothes.is/viewer/web/6aef3df90002fbfab1a43ce8eee5eb15.pdf"}}]

But evidence of other epistemo", "type": "TextQuoteSelector"}], "source": "http://unescochair-cbrsr.org/pdf/resource/RFA.pdf"}], "updated": "2018-11-09T00:19:43.537779+00:00", "tags": [], "uri": "http://unescochair-cbrsr.org/pdf/resource/RFA.pdf", "group": "__world__", "text": "The question is whether many of them can even be "written" or catalogued now, without bias.", "id": "KBgFguO1EeiZH0clqSWLHg", "document": {"title": ["Decolonization of knowledge, epistemicide, participatory research and higher education"]}, "user": "acct:CSG@hypothes.is", "links": {"html": "https://hypothes.is/a/KBgFguO1EeiZH0clqSWLHg", "json": "https://hypothes.is/api/annotations/KBgFguO1EeiZH0clqSWLHg", "incontext": "https://hyp.is/KBgFguO1EeiZH0clqSWLHg/unescochair-cbrsr.org/pdf/resource/RFA.pdf"}}, {"created": "2018-11-09T00:15:40.280083+00:00", "permissions": {"read": ["group:__world__"], "update": ["acct:KariGustafson@hypothes.is"], "delete": ["acct:KariGustafson@hypothes.is"], "admin": ["acct:KariGustafson@hypothes.is"]}, "user_info": {"display_name": null}, "hidden": false, "flagged": false, "target": [{"selector": [{"end": 11643, "start": 11109, "type": "TextPositionSelector"}, {"prefix": " culture of knowledge asymmetry.", "exact": " Knowledge asymmetry occurs when the people who provide knowledge do not benefit from the gathering and organizing of that knowledge. Knowledge, they said:has been extracted, documented without any acknowledgement to the source. The documented knowledge has not been communicated to the knowledge holder for feedback. These practices have not only impoverished the knowledge holders by pushing them further down in the oblivion, but also have hampered the growth of an informal knowledge system, that is robust in nurturing creativity", "suffix": ".(Honey Bee, n.d.)They called th", "type": "TextQuoteSelector"}], "source": "http://unescochair-cbrsr.org/pdf/resource/RFA.pdf"}], "updated": "2018-11-09T00:17:32.042813+00:00", "tags": [], "uri": "http://unescochair-cbrsr.org/pdf/resource/RFA.pdf", "group": "__world__", "text": "I was recently looking through the submission guidelines for an autism research conference I was considering attending, and ran across these two conditions:

1. Any work with human or animal subjects reported in the abstract complies with the guiding policies and principles for experimental procedures endorsed by the National Institutes of Health.
2. Each author has given consent to appear as an author. Each author will automatically receive notice of abstract submission, and will be able to view it at any time.

I'm pretty sure these are standard phrasing for conflict of interest, ethics, and protection of intellectual property, so it is not this particular conference I am commenting on, but the general attitude toward the different actors it describes, that is common to most such conferences.

Persons with ASD diagnoses are "human subjects," protected from being damaged in the same way animal subjects are, but only researchers' / authors' knowledge and insights are valued. It is presumed, I suppose, that the human subjects had signed their rights away in their informed consent document before participating in the research, and therefore do not need to be considered. I wonder, though, if one can actually assume that everyone participating in social science research is truly and meaningfully "informed" of the way that their bodies and behaviors are transformed into someone else's property.

This, as well, is definitely an example of knowledge asymmetry, and "human subjects" are often being "pushed... further down in the oblivion."", "id": "lxojbOO0EeiYS3eks5n-qQ", "document": {"title": ["Decolonization of knowledge, epistemicide, participatory research and higher education"]}, "user": "acct:KariGustafson@hypothes.is", "links": {"html": "https://hypothes.is/a/lxojbOO0EeiYS3eks5n-qQ", "json": "https://hypothes.is/api/annotations/lxojbOO0EeiYS3eks5n-qQ", "incontext": "https://hyp.is/lxojbOO0EeiYS3eks5n-qQ/unescochair-cbrsr.org/pdf/resource/RFA.pdf"}}, {"created": "2018-11-08T23:58:54.737414+00:00", "permissions": {"read": ["group:__world__"], "update": ["acct:KariGustafson@hypothes.is"], "delete": ["acct:KariGustafson@hypothes.is"], "admin": ["acct:KariGustafson@hypothes.is"]}, "user_info": {"display_name": null}, "hidden": false, "references": ["MLE35ON1EeiUULNiKGHRDw", "x1EseOOhEeiE2GOydvTgrA"], "flagged": false, "target": [{"source": "http://unescochair-cbrsr.org/pdf/resource/RFA.pdf"}], "updated": "2018-11-08T23:58:54.737414+00:00", "tags": [], "uri": "http://unescochair-cbrsr.org/pdf/resource/RFA.pdf", "group": "__world__", "text": "Definitely! (If you feel like it.) ", "exact": "Is the global North stuck in a rut in the path of history that does not allow for the existence of histories other than the universal history of the West?", "suffix": "Knowledge democracyKnowledge dem", "type": "TextQuoteSelector"}], "source": "http://unescochair-cbrsr.org/pdf/resource/RFA.pdf"}], "updated": "2018-11-08T16:52:16.849432+00:00", "tags": [], "uri": "http://unescochair-cbrsr.org/pdf/resource/RFA.pdf", "group": "__world__", "text": "I like that this article highlights the disadvantages of colonialism for the Global North, not just the Global South", "id": "od4-mON2EeibRNO4OrMX7w", "document": {"title": ["Decolonization of knowledge, epistemicide, participatory research and higher education"]}, "user": "acct:aliceLF@hypothes.is", "links": {"html": "https://hypothes.is/a/od4-mON2EeibRNO4OrMX7w", "json": "https://hypothes.is/api/annotations/od4-mON2EeibRNO4OrMX7w", "incontext": "https://hyp.is/od4-mON2EeibRNO4OrMX7w/unescochair-cbrsr.org/pdf/resource/RFA.pdf"}}, {"created": "2018-11-08T16:41:50.039864+00:00", "permissions": {"read": ["group:__world__"], "update": ["acct:aliceLF@hypothes.is"], "delete": ["acct:aliceLF@hypothes.is"], "admin": ["acct:aliceLF@hypothes.is"]}, "user_info": {"display_name": "Alice Fleerackers"}, "hidden": false, "flagged": false, "target": [{"selector": [{"end": 9128, "start": 8979, "type": "TextPositionSelector"}, {"prefix": "of our communities to this day. ", "exact": "The contemporary debate about private higher education institutions takes the idea of knowledge as a commodity to be bought and sold to another level", "suffix": ".These new academies came into b", "type": "TextQuoteSelector"}], "source": "http://unescochair-cbrsr.org/pdf/resource/RFA.pdf"}], "updated": "2018-11-08T16:41:50.039864+00:00", "tags": [], "uri": "http://unescochair-cbrsr.org/pdf/resource/RFA.pdf", "group": "__world__", "text": "The concepts of scarcity and value are so strongly connected. If access to knowledge isn't seen as something exclusive, can it still be seen as valuable?  ", "id": "MLE35ON1EeiUULNiKGHRDw", "document": {"title": ["Decolonization of knowledge, epistemicide, participatory research and higher education"]}, "user": "acct:aliceLF@hypothes.is", "links": {"html": "https://hypothes.is/a/MLE35ON1EeiUULNiKGHRDw", "json": "https://hypothes.is/api/annotations/MLE35ON1EeiUULNiKGHRDw", "incontext": "https://hyp.is/MLE35ON1EeiUULNiKGHRDw/unescochair-cbrsr.org/pdf/resource/RFA.pdf"}}]

"tags": [], "uri": "http://eprints.rclis.org/23682/1/Current-socio-published-non-Sage-format.pdf", "group": "__world__", "text": "Yes, there's this idea I've heard quite regularly that as soon as an author makes a payment in their research production (e.g., paying for OA), it automatically demotes or devalues the prestige/relevance/rigour/quality of the work: It doesn't matter that the purpose for payment was to make the work open access, but instead it has now entered a category of \"you had to pay a journal to publish your work, therefore it should be equated with publishing in a predatory journal.\" Maybe this idea is pervasive because it can be equated (to be clear i think unfairly so) with something like \"buying likes or visibility\"", "id": "BAlnquTGEeiBiC9Yn3CJcw", "document": {"title": ["Current-socio-published-non-Sage-format.pdf"]}, "user": "acct:camilleweinsheimer@hypothes.is", "links": {"html": "https://hypothes.is/a/BAlnquTGEeiBiC9Yn3CJcw", "json": avenues of research, but it's hard for me to imagine that it would be the obvious case over cooperation/collaboration... at least, it seems more likely to me that competition in this way would be an inefficient method to reach discovery & knowledge production", "id": "iRCHZOTEEeiuNR_nvqkkJA", "document": {"title": ["Current-socio-published-non-Sage-format.pdf"]}, "user": "http://eprints.rclis.org/23682/1/Current-socio-published-non-Sage-format.pdf", "group": "__world__", "text": "I am surprised by this! \nTo the \"fashionable themes\" point above, I've heard discussions that I've found to be quite persuasive about how this pressure to publish in the highest-impact journals, only because they have high impact factors, is stifling creativity - researchers are writing for a very select group of individuals who may be perpetuating the same ideas (perhaps one of those trendy topics) - at stake is the development of new ideas, collaborations, and overall important developments that don't occur or prosper in vacuum. ", "suffix": "The exclusive use of SCI indicat", "type": "TextQuoteSelector"}], "source": "http://eprints.rclis.org/23682/1/Current-socio-published-non-Sage-format.pdf"}], "updated": "2018-11-08T01:15:39.335077+00:00", "tags": [], "uri": "http://eprints.rclis.org/23682/1/Current-socio-published-non-Sage-format.pdf", "group": "__world__", "text": "Web of Science (previously known as Web of Knowledge) is an online subscription-based scientific citation indexing service originally produced by the Institute for Scientific Information (ISI), later maintained by Clarivate Analytics (previously the Intellectual Property and Science business of Thomson Reuters[1]), that provides a comprehensive citation search. It gives access to multiple databases that reference cross-disciplinary research, which allows for in-depth exploration of specialized sub-fields within an academic or scientific discipline.[2]", "id": "zeIBiOLzEeizNx_fpwwFTw", "document": {"title": ["Current-socio-published-non-Sage-format.pdf"]}, "user": "acct:linnteetzel@hypothes.is", "links": {"html": "https://hypothes.is/a/zeIBiOLzEeizNx_fpwwFTw", "json": "https://hypothes.is/api/annotations/zeIBiOLzEeizNx_fpwwFTw", "incontext": "https://hyp.is/zeIBiOLzEeizNx_fpwwFTw/eprints.rclis.org/23682/1/Current-socio-published-non-Sage-format.pdf"}}, {"created": "2018-11-08T01:12:38.241219+00:00", "permissions": {"read": ["group:__world__"], "update": ["acct:linnteetzel@hypothes.is"], "delete": ["acct:linnteetzel@hypothes.is"], "admin": ["acct:linnteetzel@hypothes.is"]}, "user_info": {"display_name": null}, "hidden": false, "flagged": false, "target": [{"selector": [{"end": 21531, "start": 21128, "type": "TextPositionSelector"}, {"prefix": "y in these journals. Of course, ", "exact": "the majority of the selected titles emerge from OECD countries. Collectively, through their editorial policies, they decide what questions are important, and thus create a kind of collective, flexible, largely unplanned, yet narrowly controlled, form of science policy for the world. It is this collective device that, incidentally, largely accounts for curious knowledge gaps such as neglected diseases", "suffix": ". The efficiency of the whole op", "type": "TextQuoteSelector"}], "source": "http://eprints.rclis.org/23682/1/Current-socio-published-non-Sage-format.pdf"}], "updated": "2018-11-08T01:12:38.241219+00:00", "tags": [], "uri": "http://eprints.rclis.org/23682/1/Current-socio-published-non-Sage-format.pdf", "group": "__world__", "text": "This is an interesting idea, worth considering.  We have spoken about different ways of making knowledge public in this course. ", "type": "TextQuoteSelector"}], "source": "http://eprints.rclis.org/23682/1/Current-socio-published-non-Sage-format.pdf"}], "updated": "2018-11-08T00:30:47.196040+00:00", "tags": [], "uri": "http://eprints.rclis.org/23682/1/Current-socio-published-non-Sage-format.pdf", "group": "__world__", "text": "From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia\n\nThe Science Citation Index (SCI) is a citation index originally produced by the Institute for Scientific Information (ISI) and created by Eugene Garfield. It was officially launched in 1964. It is now owned by Clarivate Analytics (previously the Intellectual Property and Science business of Thomson Reuters).[1][2][3][4] The larger version (Science Citation Index Expanded) covers more than 8,500 notable and significant journals, across 150 disciplines, from 1900 to the present. These are alternatively described as the world's leading journals of science and technology, because of a rigorous selection process.[5][6][7]\n\nThe index is made available online through different platforms, such as the Web of Science[8][9] and SciSearch.[10] (There are also CD and printed editions, covering a smaller number of journals). This database allows a researcher to identify which later articles have cited any particular earlier article, or have cited the articles of any particular author, or have been cited most frequently. Thomson Reuters also markets several subsets of this database, termed \"Specialty Citation Indexes\",[11] such as the Neuroscience Citation Index[12] and the Chemistry Citation Index.[13]", "id": "iUpQYuLtEeirUvfk_mJRUA", "document": {"title": ["Current-socio-published-non-Sage-format.pdf"]}, "user": "acct:linnteetzel@hypothes.is", "links": {"html": "https://hypothes.is/a/iUpQYuLtEeirUvfk_mJRUA", "json": "https://hypothes.is/api/annotations/iUpQYuLtEeirUvfk_mJRUA", "incontext": "https://hyp.is/iUpQYuLtEeirUvfk_mJRUA/eprints.rclis.org/23682/1/Current-socio-published-non-Sage-format.pdf"}}, {"created": "2018-11-07T23:46:45.886619+00:00", "permissions": {"read": ["group:__world__"], "update": ["acct:anastasiak@hypothes.is"], "delete": ["acct:anastasiak@hypothes.is"], "admin": ["acct:anastasiak@hypothes.is"]}, "user_info": {"display_name": null}, "hidden": false, "flagged": false, "target": [{"selector": [{"end": 48905, "start": 48769, "type": "TextPositionSelector"}, {"prefix": "ul tool to favor quality. I guess I am just curious what the average "cost per download" of an article is. It would be interesting to be able to compare that to what the average price per download is. 

Of course, *if* an article were read/accessed/downloaded an infinite amount of times, the cost would reach zero. But this obviously isn't the case, and so there's still, technically, a kind of unit cost associated with each article, right? At least, that's how you would think about it from a traditional business perspective, no? Maybe I've worked in books for too long...

it is interesting to look at some newer (especially open sciency) scholarly communication strategies.

Using frameworks to easily do the typesetting, uploads to pre-print platforms such as provided by the OSF, dissemination through social networks, open peer review such as provided by F1000.

", "exact": "“University presses and disciplinary associations were founded to disseminate research in the original cycle of scholarly communication. It's also the smaller society that moves around to different continents/ countries each meeting - again, I'm not sure how this actually compares proportionally to others, but I think there's something gained from the "feeling" of international connectedness that I haven't experiences in the larger scientific communities", "id": "I-3sdOi6Eeikx1M-KxUU1g", "document": {"title": ["The Oligopoly of Academic Publishers in the Digital Era"]}, "user": "acct:camilleweinsheimer@hypothes.is", "links": {"html": "https://hypothes.is/a/I-3sdOi6Eeikx1M-KxUU1g", "json": "https://hypothes.is/api/annotations/I-3sdOi6Eeikx1M-KxUU1g", "incontext": "https://hyp.is/I-3sdOi6Eeikx1M-KxUU1g/journals.plos.org/plosone/article?id=10.1371/journal.pone.0127502"}}, {"created": "2018-11-15T09:22:41.122883+00:00", "permissions": {"read": ["group:__world__"], "update": ["acct:camilleweinsheimer@hypothes.is"], "delete": ["acct:camilleweinsheimer@hypothes.is"], "admin": ["acct:camilleweinsheimer@hypothes.is"]}, "user_info": {"display_name": "camilleweinsheimer"}, "hidden": false, "references": ["ndspluhTEeiToCe6PjZ4qg"], "flagged": false, "target": [{"source": "https://journals.plos.org/plosone/article?id=10.1371/journal.pone.0127502"}], "updated": "2018-11-15T09:22:41.122883+00:00", "tags": [], "uri": "https://journals.plos.org/plosone/article?id=10.1371/journal.pone.0127502", "group": "__world__", "text": "What an interesting parallel!

Those few companies that publish the most research and make the most money off those publications don't want anything to change because then it reduces their profits. This section mentions libraries, which are always at the losing end when it comes to budgeting and money. If these few companies that are making so much money off publications of research really cared about dissemination of knowledge, then I think the reality would look different. Marketing? 
I definitely understand this point, but I would argue that you still need *some* infrastructure to publish. Especially the question of diffusion. There is so much information circulating online that having some kind of outreach strategy is essential.
